trans-unit.source: Deploy and manage backup for Windows Server/Client using PowerShell | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Deploy and manage backup for Windows Server/Client using PowerShell | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to deploy and manage Azure Backup using PowerShell
trans-unit.target: Learn how to deploy and manage Azure Backup using PowerShell

trans-unit.source: Deploy and manage backup to Azure for Windows Server/Windows Client using PowerShell
trans-unit.target: Deploy and manage backup to Azure for Windows Server/Windows Client using PowerShell

trans-unit.source: This article shows you how to use PowerShell to set up Azure Backup on Windows Server or Windows Client, and to manage backup and recovery.
trans-unit.target: This article shows you how to use PowerShell to set up Azure Backup on Windows Server or Windows Client, and to manage backup and recovery.

trans-unit.source: Setup and Registration
trans-unit.target: Setup and Registration

trans-unit.source: The following setup and registration tasks can be automated with PowerShell:
trans-unit.target: The following setup and registration tasks can be automated with PowerShell:

trans-unit.target: Create a backup vault

trans-unit.target: Installing the Azure Backup agent

trans-unit.target: Registering with the Azure Backup service

trans-unit.target: Networking settings

trans-unit.target: Encryption settings

trans-unit.source: Create a backup vault
trans-unit.target: Create a backup vault

trans-unit.source: You can create a new backup vault using the **New-AzureBackupVault** commandlet.
trans-unit.target: You can create a new backup vault using the **New-AzureBackupVault** commandlet.

trans-unit.source: The backup vault is an ARM resource, so you need to place it within a Resource Group.
trans-unit.target: The backup vault is an ARM resource, so you need to place it within a Resource Group.

trans-unit.source: In an elevated Azure PowerShell console, run the following commands:
trans-unit.target: In an elevated Azure PowerShell console, run the following commands:

trans-unit.source: You can get a list of all the backup vaults in a given subscription using the **Get-AzureBackupVault** commandlet.
trans-unit.target: You can get a list of all the backup vaults in a given subscription using the **Get-AzureBackupVault** commandlet.

trans-unit.source: Installing the Azure Backup agent
trans-unit.target: Installing the Azure Backup agent

trans-unit.source: Before you install the Azure Backup agent, you need to have the installer downloaded and present on the Windows Server.
trans-unit.target: Before you install the Azure Backup agent, you need to have the installer downloaded and present on the Windows Server.

trans-unit.source: You can get the latest version of the installer from the [Microsoft Download Center](http://aka.ms/azurebackup_agent) or from the backup vault's Dashboard page.
trans-unit.target: You can get the latest version of the installer from the [Microsoft Download Center](http://aka.ms/azurebackup_agent) or from the backup vault's Dashboard page.

trans-unit.source: Save the installer to an easily accessible location like *C:\Downloads\*.
trans-unit.target: Save the installer to an easily accessible location like *C:\Downloads\*.

trans-unit.source: To install the agent, run the following command in an elevated PowerShell console:
trans-unit.target: To install the agent, run the following command in an elevated PowerShell console:

trans-unit.source: This installs the agent with all the default options.
trans-unit.target: This installs the agent with all the default options.

trans-unit.source: The installation takes a few minutes in the background.
trans-unit.target: The installation takes a few minutes in the background.

trans-unit.source: If you do not specify the */nu* option then the **Windows Update** window will open at the end of the installation to check for any updates.
trans-unit.target: If you do not specify the */nu* option then the **Windows Update** window will open at the end of the installation to check for any updates.

trans-unit.source: Once installed, the agent will show in the list of installed programs.
trans-unit.target: Once installed, the agent will show in the list of installed programs.

trans-unit.source: To see the list of installed programs, go to **Control Panel** > **Programs** > **Programs and Features**.
trans-unit.target: To see the list of installed programs, go to **Control Panel** > **Programs** > **Programs and Features**.

trans-unit.source: Agent installed
trans-unit.target: Agent installed

trans-unit.source: Installation options
trans-unit.target: Installation options

trans-unit.source: To see all the options available via the command-line, use the following command:
trans-unit.target: To see all the options available via the command-line, use the following command:

trans-unit.source: The available options include:
trans-unit.target: The available options include:

trans-unit.source: Option
trans-unit.target: Option

trans-unit.source: Details
trans-unit.target: Details

trans-unit.source: Default
trans-unit.target: Default

trans-unit.source: /q
trans-unit.target: /q

trans-unit.source: Quiet installation
trans-unit.target: Quiet installation

trans-unit.source: /p:"location"
trans-unit.target: /p:"location"

trans-unit.source: Path to the installation folder for the Azure Backup agent.
trans-unit.target: Path to the installation folder for the Azure Backup agent.

trans-unit.source: C:\Program Files\Microsoft Azure Recovery Services Agent
trans-unit.target: C:\Program Files\Microsoft Azure Recovery Services Agent

trans-unit.source: /s:"location"
trans-unit.target: /s:"location"

trans-unit.source: Path to the cache folder for the Azure Backup agent.
trans-unit.target: Path to the cache folder for the Azure Backup agent.

trans-unit.source: C:\Program Files\Microsoft Azure Recovery Services Agent\Scratch
trans-unit.target: C:\Program Files\Microsoft Azure Recovery Services Agent\Scratch

trans-unit.source: /m
trans-unit.target: /m

trans-unit.source: Opt-in to Microsoft Update
trans-unit.target: Opt-in to Microsoft Update

trans-unit.source: /nu
trans-unit.target: /nu

trans-unit.source: Do not Check for updates after installation is complete
trans-unit.target: Do not Check for updates after installation is complete

trans-unit.source: /d
trans-unit.target: /d

trans-unit.source: Uninstalls Microsoft Azure Recovery Services Agent
trans-unit.target: Uninstalls Microsoft Azure Recovery Services Agent

trans-unit.source: /ph
trans-unit.target: /ph

trans-unit.target: Proxy Host Address

trans-unit.target: /po

trans-unit.target: Proxy Host Port Number

trans-unit.target: /pu

trans-unit.target: Proxy Host UserName

trans-unit.target: /pw

trans-unit.target: Proxy Password

trans-unit.source: Registering with the Azure Backup service
trans-unit.target: Registering with the Azure Backup service

trans-unit.source: Before you can register with the Azure Backup service, you need to ensure that the [prerequisites](backup-configure-vault.md) are met.
trans-unit.target: Before you can register with the Azure Backup service, you need to ensure that the [prerequisites](backup-configure-vault.md) are met.

trans-unit.source: You must:
trans-unit.target: You must:

trans-unit.source: Have a valid Azure subscription
trans-unit.target: Have a valid Azure subscription

trans-unit.source: Have a backup vault
trans-unit.target: Have a backup vault

trans-unit.source: To download the vault credentials, run the **Get-AzureBackupVaultCredentials** commandlet in an Azure PowerShell console and store it in a convenient location like *C:\Downloads\*.
trans-unit.target: To download the vault credentials, run the **Get-AzureBackupVaultCredentials** commandlet in an Azure PowerShell console and store it in a convenient location like *C:\Downloads\*.

trans-unit.source: Registering the machine with the vault is done using the [Start-OBRegistration](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh770398%28v=wps.630%29.aspx) cmdlet:
trans-unit.target: Registering the machine with the vault is done using the [Start-OBRegistration](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh770398%28v=wps.630%29.aspx) cmdlet:

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.IMPORTANT] Do not use relative paths to specify the vault credentials file.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.IMPORTANT] Do not use relative paths to specify the vault credentials file.

trans-unit.source: You must provide an absolute path as an input to the cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: You must provide an absolute path as an input to the cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: Networking settings
trans-unit.target: Networking settings

trans-unit.source: When the connectivity of the Windows machine to the internet is through a proxy server, the proxy settings can also be provided to the agent.
trans-unit.target: When the connectivity of the Windows machine to the internet is through a proxy server, the proxy settings can also be provided to the agent.

trans-unit.source: In this example, there is no proxy server, so we are explicitly clearing any proxy-related information.
trans-unit.target: In this example, there is no proxy server, so we are explicitly clearing any proxy-related information.

trans-unit.source: Bandwidth usage can also be controlled with the options of ```work hour bandwidth``` and ```non-work hour bandwidth``` for a given set of days of the week.
trans-unit.target: Bandwidth usage can also be controlled with the options of ```work hour bandwidth``` and ```non-work hour bandwidth``` for a given set of days of the week.

trans-unit.source: Setting the proxy and bandwidth details is done using the [Set-OBMachineSetting](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh770409%28v=wps.630%29.aspx) cmdlet:
trans-unit.target: Setting the proxy and bandwidth details is done using the [Set-OBMachineSetting](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh770409%28v=wps.630%29.aspx) cmdlet:

trans-unit.source: Encryption settings
trans-unit.target: Encryption settings

trans-unit.source: The backup data sent to Azure Backup is encrypted to protect the confidentiality of the data.
trans-unit.target: The backup data sent to Azure Backup is encrypted to protect the confidentiality of the data.

trans-unit.source: The encryption passphrase is the "password" to decrypt the data at the time of restore.
trans-unit.target: The encryption passphrase is the "password" to decrypt the data at the time of restore.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.IMPORTANT] Keep the passphrase information safe and secure once it is set.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.IMPORTANT] Keep the passphrase information safe and secure once it is set.

trans-unit.source: You will not be able to restore data from Azure without this passphrase.
trans-unit.target: You will not be able to restore data from Azure without this passphrase.

trans-unit.source: Back up files and folders
trans-unit.target: Back up files and folders

trans-unit.source: All your backups from Windows Servers and clients to Azure Backup are governed by a policy.
trans-unit.target: All your backups from Windows Servers and clients to Azure Backup are governed by a policy.

trans-unit.source: The policy comprises three parts:
trans-unit.target: The policy comprises three parts:

trans-unit.source: A **backup schedule** that specifies when backups need to be taken and synchronized with the service.
trans-unit.target: A **backup schedule** that specifies when backups need to be taken and synchronized with the service.

trans-unit.source: A **retention schedule** that specifies how long to retain the recovery points in Azure.
trans-unit.target: A **retention schedule** that specifies how long to retain the recovery points in Azure.

trans-unit.source: A **file inclusion/exclusion specification** that dictates what should be backed up.
trans-unit.target: A **file inclusion/exclusion specification** that dictates what should be backed up.

trans-unit.source: In this document, since we're automating backup, we'll assume nothing has been configured.
trans-unit.target: In this document, since we're automating backup, we'll assume nothing has been configured.

trans-unit.source: We begin by creating a new backup policy using the [New-OBPolicy](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh770416.aspx) cmdlet and using it.
trans-unit.target: We begin by creating a new backup policy using the [New-OBPolicy](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh770416.aspx) cmdlet and using it.

trans-unit.source: At this time the policy is empty and other cmdlets are needed to define what items will be included or excluded, when backups will run, and where the backups will be stored.
trans-unit.target: At this time the policy is empty and other cmdlets are needed to define what items will be included or excluded, when backups will run, and where the backups will be stored.

trans-unit.source: Configuring the backup schedule
trans-unit.target: Configuring the backup schedule

trans-unit.source: The first of the 3 parts of a policy is the backup schedule, which is created using the [New-OBSchedule](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh770401) cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: The first of the 3 parts of a policy is the backup schedule, which is created using the [New-OBSchedule](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh770401) cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: The backup schedule defines when backups need to be taken.
trans-unit.target: The backup schedule defines when backups need to be taken.

trans-unit.source: When creating a schedule you need to specify 2 input parameters:
trans-unit.target: When creating a schedule you need to specify 2 input parameters:

trans-unit.source: **Days of the week** that the backup should run.
trans-unit.target: **Days of the week** that the backup should run.

trans-unit.source: You can run the backup job on just one day, or every day of the week, or any combination in between.
trans-unit.target: You can run the backup job on just one day, or every day of the week, or any combination in between.

trans-unit.source: **Times of the day** when the backup should run.
trans-unit.target: **Times of the day** when the backup should run.

trans-unit.source: You can define up to 3 different times of the day when the backup will be triggered.
trans-unit.target: You can define up to 3 different times of the day when the backup will be triggered.

trans-unit.source: For instance, you could configure a backup policy that runs at 4PM every Saturday and Sunday.
trans-unit.target: For instance, you could configure a backup policy that runs at 4PM every Saturday and Sunday.

trans-unit.source: The backup schedule needs to be associated with a policy, and this can be achieved by using the [Set-OBSchedule](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh770407) cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: The backup schedule needs to be associated with a policy, and this can be achieved by using the [Set-OBSchedule](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh770407) cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: Configuring a retention policy
trans-unit.target: Configuring a retention policy

trans-unit.source: The retention policy defines how long recovery points created from backup jobs are retained.
trans-unit.target: The retention policy defines how long recovery points created from backup jobs are retained.

trans-unit.source: When creating a new retention policy using the [New-OBRetentionPolicy](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh770425) cmdlet, you can specify the number of days that the backup recovery points need to be retained with Azure Backup.
trans-unit.target: When creating a new retention policy using the [New-OBRetentionPolicy](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh770425) cmdlet, you can specify the number of days that the backup recovery points need to be retained with Azure Backup.

trans-unit.source: The example below sets a retention policy of 7 days.
trans-unit.target: The example below sets a retention policy of 7 days.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] PowerShell cmdlets currently do not support the setting of long term retention policies.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] PowerShell cmdlets currently do not support the setting of long term retention policies.

trans-unit.source: Use the Azure Backup UI console to set long term retention policies.
trans-unit.target: Use the Azure Backup UI console to set long term retention policies.

trans-unit.source: The retention policy must be associated with the main policy using the cmdlet [Set-OBRetentionPolicy](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh770405):
trans-unit.target: The retention policy must be associated with the main policy using the cmdlet [Set-OBRetentionPolicy](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh770405):

trans-unit.source: Including and excluding files to be backed up
trans-unit.target: Including and excluding files to be backed up

trans-unit.source: An ```OBFileSpec``` object defines the files to be included and excluded in a backup.
trans-unit.target: An ```OBFileSpec``` object defines the files to be included and excluded in a backup.

trans-unit.source: This is a set of rules that scope out the protected files and folders on a machine.
trans-unit.target: This is a set of rules that scope out the protected files and folders on a machine.

trans-unit.source: You can have as many file inclusion or exclusion rules as required, and associate them with a policy.
trans-unit.target: You can have as many file inclusion or exclusion rules as required, and associate them with a policy.

trans-unit.source: When creating a new OBFileSpec object, you can:
trans-unit.target: When creating a new OBFileSpec object, you can:

trans-unit.source: Specify the files and folders to be included
trans-unit.target: Specify the files and folders to be included

trans-unit.source: Specify the files and folders to be excluded
trans-unit.target: Specify the files and folders to be excluded

trans-unit.source: Specify recursive backup of data in a folder (or) whether only the top-level files in the specified folder should be backed up.
trans-unit.target: Specify recursive backup of data in a folder (or) whether only the top-level files in the specified folder should be backed up.

trans-unit.source: The latter is achieved by using the -NonRecursive flag in the New-OBFileSpec command.
trans-unit.target: The latter is achieved by using the -NonRecursive flag in the New-OBFileSpec command.

trans-unit.source: In the example below, we'll back up volume C: and D: and exclude the OS binaries in the Windows folder and any temporary folders.
trans-unit.target: In the example below, we'll back up volume C: and D: and exclude the OS binaries in the Windows folder and any temporary folders.

trans-unit.source: To do so we'll create two file specifications using the [New-OBFileSpec](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh770408) cmdlet - one for inclusion and one for exclusion.
trans-unit.target: To do so we'll create two file specifications using the [New-OBFileSpec](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh770408) cmdlet - one for inclusion and one for exclusion.

trans-unit.source: Once the file specifications have been created, they're associated with the policy using the [Add-OBFileSpec](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh770424) cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: Once the file specifications have been created, they're associated with the policy using the [Add-OBFileSpec](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh770424) cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: Applying the policy
trans-unit.target: Applying the policy

trans-unit.source: Now the policy object is complete and has an associated backup schedule, retention policy, and an inclusion/exclusion list of files.
trans-unit.target: Now the policy object is complete and has an associated backup schedule, retention policy, and an inclusion/exclusion list of files.

trans-unit.source: This policy can now be committed for Azure Backup to use.
trans-unit.target: This policy can now be committed for Azure Backup to use.

trans-unit.source: Before you apply the newly created policy ensure that there are no existing backup policies associated with the server by using the [Remove-OBPolicy](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh770415) cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: Before you apply the newly created policy ensure that there are no existing backup policies associated with the server by using the [Remove-OBPolicy](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh770415) cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: Removing the policy will prompt for confirmation.
trans-unit.target: Removing the policy will prompt for confirmation.

trans-unit.source: To skip the confirmation use the ```-Confirm:$false``` flag with the cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: To skip the confirmation use the ```-Confirm:$false``` flag with the cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: Committing the policy object is done using the [Set-OBPolicy](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh770421) cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: Committing the policy object is done using the [Set-OBPolicy](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh770421) cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: This will also ask for confirmation.
trans-unit.target: This will also ask for confirmation.

trans-unit.source: To skip the confirmation use the ```-Confirm:$false``` flag with the cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: To skip the confirmation use the ```-Confirm:$false``` flag with the cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: You can view the details of the existing backup policy using the [Get-OBPolicy](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh770406) cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: You can view the details of the existing backup policy using the [Get-OBPolicy](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh770406) cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: You can drill-down further using the [Get-OBSchedule](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh770423) cmdlet for the backup schedule and the [Get-OBRetentionPolicy](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh770427) cmdlet for the retention policies
trans-unit.target: You can drill-down further using the [Get-OBSchedule](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh770423) cmdlet for the backup schedule and the [Get-OBRetentionPolicy](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh770427) cmdlet for the retention policies

trans-unit.source: Performing an ad-hoc backup
trans-unit.target: Performing an ad-hoc backup

trans-unit.source: Once a backup policy has been set the backups will occur per the schedule.
trans-unit.target: Once a backup policy has been set the backups will occur per the schedule.

trans-unit.source: Triggering an ad-hoc backup is also possible using the [Start-OBBackup](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh770426) cmdlet:
trans-unit.target: Triggering an ad-hoc backup is also possible using the [Start-OBBackup](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh770426) cmdlet:

trans-unit.source: Restore data from Azure Backup
trans-unit.target: Restore data from Azure Backup

trans-unit.source: This section will guide you through the steps for automating recovery of data from Azure Backup.
trans-unit.target: This section will guide you through the steps for automating recovery of data from Azure Backup.

trans-unit.source: Doing so involves the following steps:
trans-unit.target: Doing so involves the following steps:

trans-unit.source: Pick the source volume
trans-unit.target: Pick the source volume

trans-unit.source: Choose a backup point to restore
trans-unit.target: Choose a backup point to restore

trans-unit.source: Choose an item to restore
trans-unit.target: Choose an item to restore

trans-unit.source: Trigger the restore process
trans-unit.target: Trigger the restore process

trans-unit.source: Picking the source volume
trans-unit.target: Picking the source volume

trans-unit.source: In order to restore an item from Azure Backup, you first need to identify the source of the item.
trans-unit.target: In order to restore an item from Azure Backup, you first need to identify the source of the item.

trans-unit.source: Since we're executing the commands in the context of a Windows Server or a Windows client, the machine is already identified.
trans-unit.target: Since we're executing the commands in the context of a Windows Server or a Windows client, the machine is already identified.

trans-unit.source: The next step in identifying the source is to identify the volume containing it.
trans-unit.target: The next step in identifying the source is to identify the volume containing it.

trans-unit.source: A list of volumes or sources being backed up from this machine can be retrieved by executing the [Get-OBRecoverableSource](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh770410) cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: A list of volumes or sources being backed up from this machine can be retrieved by executing the [Get-OBRecoverableSource](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh770410) cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: This command returns an array of all the sources backed up from this server/client.
trans-unit.target: This command returns an array of all the sources backed up from this server/client.

trans-unit.source: Choosing a backup point to restore
trans-unit.target: Choosing a backup point to restore

trans-unit.source: The list of backup points can be retrieved by executing the [Get-OBRecoverableItem](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh770399.aspx) cmdlet with appropriate parameters.
trans-unit.target: The list of backup points can be retrieved by executing the [Get-OBRecoverableItem](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh770399.aspx) cmdlet with appropriate parameters.

trans-unit.source: In our example, we’ll choose the latest backup point for the source volume *D:* and use it to recover a specific file.
trans-unit.target: In our example, we’ll choose the latest backup point for the source volume *D:* and use it to recover a specific file.

trans-unit.source: The object ```$rps``` is an array of backup points.
trans-unit.target: The object ```$rps``` is an array of backup points.

trans-unit.source: The first element is the latest point and the Nth element is the oldest point.
trans-unit.target: The first element is the latest point and the Nth element is the oldest point.

trans-unit.source: To choose the latest point, we will use ```$rps[0]```.
trans-unit.target: To choose the latest point, we will use ```$rps[0]```.

trans-unit.source: Choosing an item to restore
trans-unit.target: Choosing an item to restore

trans-unit.source: To identify the exact file or folder to restore, recursively use the [Get-OBRecoverableItem](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh770399.aspx) cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: To identify the exact file or folder to restore, recursively use the [Get-OBRecoverableItem](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh770399.aspx) cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: That way the folder hierarchy can be browsed solely using the ```Get-OBRecoverableItem```.
trans-unit.target: That way the folder hierarchy can be browsed solely using the ```Get-OBRecoverableItem```.

trans-unit.source: In this example, if we want to restore the file *finances.xls* we can reference that using the object ```$filesFolders[1]```.
trans-unit.target: In this example, if we want to restore the file *finances.xls* we can reference that using the object ```$filesFolders[1]```.

trans-unit.source: You can also search for items to restore using the ```Get-OBRecoverableItem``` cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: You can also search for items to restore using the ```Get-OBRecoverableItem``` cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: In our example, to search for *finances.xls* we could get a handle on the file by running this command:
trans-unit.target: In our example, to search for *finances.xls* we could get a handle on the file by running this command:

trans-unit.source: Triggering the restore process
trans-unit.target: Triggering the restore process

trans-unit.source: To trigger the restore process, we first need to specify the recovery options.
trans-unit.target: To trigger the restore process, we first need to specify the recovery options.

trans-unit.source: This can be done by using the [New-OBRecoveryOption](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh770417.aspx) cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: This can be done by using the [New-OBRecoveryOption](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh770417.aspx) cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: For this example, let's assume that we want to restore the files to *C:\temp*.
trans-unit.target: For this example, let's assume that we want to restore the files to *C:\temp*.

trans-unit.source: Let's also assume that we want to skip files that already exist on the destination folder *C:\temp*.
trans-unit.target: Let's also assume that we want to skip files that already exist on the destination folder *C:\temp*.

trans-unit.source: To create such a recovery option, use the following command:
trans-unit.target: To create such a recovery option, use the following command:

trans-unit.source: Now trigger restore by using the [Start-OBRecovery](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh770402.aspx) command on the selected ```$item``` from the output of the ```Get-OBRecoverableItem``` cmdlet:
trans-unit.target: Now trigger restore by using the [Start-OBRecovery](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh770402.aspx) command on the selected ```$item``` from the output of the ```Get-OBRecoverableItem``` cmdlet:

trans-unit.source: Uninstalling the Azure Backup agent
trans-unit.target: Uninstalling the Azure Backup agent

trans-unit.source: Uninstalling the Azure Backup agent can be done by using the following command:
trans-unit.target: Uninstalling the Azure Backup agent can be done by using the following command:

trans-unit.source: Uninstalling the agent binaries from the machine has some consequences to consider:
trans-unit.target: Uninstalling the agent binaries from the machine has some consequences to consider:

trans-unit.source: It removes the file-filter from the machine, and tracking of changes is stopped.
trans-unit.target: It removes the file-filter from the machine, and tracking of changes is stopped.

trans-unit.source: All policy information is removed from the machine, but the policy information continues to be stored in the service.
trans-unit.target: All policy information is removed from the machine, but the policy information continues to be stored in the service.

trans-unit.source: All backup schedules are removed, and no further backups are taken.
trans-unit.target: All backup schedules are removed, and no further backups are taken.

trans-unit.source: However, the data stored in Azure remains and is retained as per the retention policy setup by you.
trans-unit.target: However, the data stored in Azure remains and is retained as per the retention policy setup by you.

trans-unit.source: Older points are automatically aged out.
trans-unit.target: Older points are automatically aged out.

trans-unit.source: Remote management
trans-unit.target: Remote management

trans-unit.source: All the management around the Azure Backup agent, policies, and data sources can be done remotely through PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: All the management around the Azure Backup agent, policies, and data sources can be done remotely through PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: The machine that will be managed remotely needs to be prepared correctly.
trans-unit.target: The machine that will be managed remotely needs to be prepared correctly.

trans-unit.source: By default, the WinRM service is configured for manual startup.
trans-unit.target: By default, the WinRM service is configured for manual startup.

trans-unit.source: The startup type must be set to *Automatic* and the service should be started.
trans-unit.target: The startup type must be set to *Automatic* and the service should be started.

trans-unit.source: To verify that the WinRM service is running, the value of the Status property should be *Running*.
trans-unit.target: To verify that the WinRM service is running, the value of the Status property should be *Running*.

trans-unit.source: PowerShell should be configured for remoting.
trans-unit.target: PowerShell should be configured for remoting.

trans-unit.source: The machine can now be managed remotely - starting from the installation of the agent.
trans-unit.target: The machine can now be managed remotely - starting from the installation of the agent.

trans-unit.source: For example, the following script copies the agent to the remote machine and installs it.
trans-unit.target: For example, the following script copies the agent to the remote machine and installs it.

trans-unit.source: Next steps
trans-unit.target: Next steps

trans-unit.target: For more information about Azure Backup for Windows Server/Client see

trans-unit.target: Back up Windows Servers
